markdownRemark.html:
In a recent discussion between Ben Horowitz and Tim Ferris, Horowitz, promoting his new book, What You Do Is Who You Are, notes that:

A culture is not a set of beliefs, it’s a set of actions.

Culture is paramount in startups - and not just to founders. Employees at early-stage firms are not only attempting to dent the universe through their work, but are also seeking to shape the culture that enables this work.

I

  • Founders should take heed while on week-long retreats to “discover” their values
  • When culture is just something written down in a google doc and not realized per actions
  • Leadership is responsible for ensuring culture remains a shared set of actions, not beliefs

And that has to be across every dimension of the culture - you have to kind of program it in. Or, you are not going to have it. You’re going to talk it.

  • More than anyone, leaders actions are under a microscope
  • Seemingly trivial actions contrary to values has an outsized effect

If you talk it, and don’t do it, then your culture becomes your hypocrisy

  • Culture is paramount to startup employees
  • Could there be a danger of fanaticism?
  • You join a firm because you believe in the vision and culture
  • If the values are not honored by leadership, will employees continue to buy into their vision?
